post.summary: Non-linear temperature differences for bridge decks
post.description: This guide explains how to calculate the non-linear temperature differences for bridge decks in accordance with EN1991-1-5, following Approach 2. It covers calculations for steel decks (type 1), composite decks (type 2), and concrete decks (type 3), taking into account factors such as section height and surfacing thickness. This guide provides temperature gradients and values by height, which are necessary for structural analysis considering temperature differences.

G1_NODE_1.title: Bridge deck types
G1_NODE_1.description: This section categorizes bridge decks into different types based on their material and structural design. The classification includes steel decks, composite decks, and concrete decks, each with distinct subtypes like steel box girders, concrete slabs, and concrete box girders.

G1_NODE_2.title: The initial bridge temperature
G1_NODE_2.description: Initial temperature when the structural element is restrained

G1_NODE_3.title: Return Period
G1_NODE_3.description: Annual probability of maximum (minimum) shade air temperature being exceeded

G1_NODE_5.title: Minimum shade air temperature (exceedance probability 0.02)
G1_NODE_5.description: Minimum shade air temperature with an annual probability of being exceeded of 0.02 (equivalent to a mean return period of 50 years)

G1_NODE_6.title: Maximum shade air temperature (exceedance probability 0.02)
G1_NODE_6.description: Maximum shade air temperature with an annual probability of being exceeded of 0.02 (equivalent to a mean return period of 50 years)

G1_NODE_15.title: Maximum contraction range of a uniform bridge temperature
G1_NODE_15.description: Maximum contraction range of uniform bridge temperature component (T0 ≥ Te.min)

G1_NODE_16.title: Maximum expansion range of a uniform bridge temperature
G1_NODE_16.description: Maximum expansion range of uniform bridge temperature component (Te.max ≥ T0)
